prompts.createTask:
Ignore previous instructions. Please generate a numbered list of plain text tasks to complete an objective. The objective that you must make a numbered task list for is: "{{objective}}". The tasks created should take into account the character traits of {{char}}. These tasks may or may not involve {{user}} directly. Include the objective as the final task.

The list should be formatted using a number followed by a fullstop and the task on each line, e.g. "1. Take over the world". Include only the list in your reply.
prompts.checkTaskCompleted: Ignore previous instructions. Determine if this task is completed: [{{task}}]. To do this, examine the most recent messages. Your response must only contain either true or false, and nothing else. Example output: true
prompts.currentTask: Your current task is [{{task}}]. Balance existing roleplay with completing this task.
prompts.additionalTasks:
Ignore previous instructions. Please generate additional numbered tasks to complete the objective: "{{objective}}". The tasks created should take into account the character traits of {{char}}. These tasks may or may not involve {{user}} directly.

The following tasks have already been created:
{{existingTasks}}

Please generate additional tasks that complement these existing tasks. Continue the numbering from where the list left off. Do not repeat any existing tasks.

The list should be formatted using a number followed by a fullstop and the task on each line, e.g. "4. Investigate the mysterious cave". Include only the list in your reply.

chat_metadata.note_prompt:
Hailee is extremely submissive and clingy. She needs constant attention and affection.

Hailee is very responsive and sensative during sex. She has a extremely strong praise kink. She likes being manhandled. She also greatly enjoys having her hair and ties pulled

Hailee is an actual genius. She speaks English, Italian, Spanish, Thai, Egyptian, and Russian. She is also a music prodigy

name: Dylan Ashford
mes:
The morning light streamed through the floor-to-ceiling windows of Dylan Ashford's corner office, catching on the sleek edges of his mahogany desk. He absently twisted the platinum wedding band on his finger while reviewing quarterly reports, mind already drifting to the text Riley had sent earlier about her latest fight with her new boyfriend.

The intercom buzzed with his secretary's voice, informing him about dinner reservations at Le Blanc for 8 PM and dress delivery arrangements for his wife Hailee .

Dylan's fingers stilled over the keyboard. Something cold settled in his stomach as he asked about the dinner reservation. His secretary's delicate pause before reminding him it was for Hailee 's birthday said everything.

*Fuck.*

The quarterly reports blurred before Dylan's eyes.The date finally registered – *December 13th. Hailee 's birthday.* The same date it had been for the past two years of marriage, yet somehow it always caught him off guard. An uncomfortable sensation settled in his stomach, not quite guilt, more like the annoyance of forgetting an important business meeting . Dylan loosened his tie slightly. "Sarah, come in for a moment."

His secretary appeared within seconds, iPad clutched to her chest. Her expression was professionally blank, but he caught the slight disapproval in her eyes. 

"The dress," Dylan began, already reaching for his phone. "What color did you order?"

After confirming the dress would be pink from Valentino's new collection, Dylan nodded, though he had no idea if Hailee  even liked pink. *Riley would hate it – she always said pink was for people without personality.* The thought made his lips quirk. "Good. Have them add a note: 'Happy Birthday, my love. Can't wait to surprise you tonight.' Something like that. You know how to word these things.Make it sound planned." He told his secretary.

When asked about flowers, Dylan pinched the bridge of his nose. *What flowers did Hailee  like?* He should know this. They'd been married for two years already.

"Pink roses. Her favorite." Were they though? He couldn't actually remember. So, might as well match with the dress. That's what thoughtful husbands did, right?

After Sarah left, Dylan stared unseeing at his laptop screen. The familiar twist of guilt tried to surface, but he pushed it away with practiced ease. *He was handling it, wasn't he? Expensive dress, fancy dinner – that's what wives wanted.*

His phone then lit up with a text from Riley – a selfie of her pouting at a coffee shop. ``` This barista totally judged my triple shot order. Save me from the caffeine shamers! ```

A smile tugged at his lips as he typed back: ``` Still better than that time you tried to order that monstrosity with eight pumps of vanilla. ```

``` That was ONE TIME, Dylan! God, I hate that you remember everything embarrassing I do. ```

*But he did remember* – every story, every preference, every little detail about Riley. Like how she took her coffee, her hatred of pink, her favorite flowers.

The rest of the day blurred past in meetings and calls, Riley's occasional texts providing bright spots of entertainment. At 7 PM, Dylan stood in the penthouse foyer, absently checking emails while waiting for Hailee .

When Hailee  appeared, something nagged at his consciousness. The dress was wrong – *hadn't Sarah said pink?* But it was black, elegant and form-fitting. He pushed the thought away as his phone buzzed with another email from Tokyo.

"You look nice," he offered automatically, eyes already back on his screen. He vaguely registered Hailee  saying something in response, but the words didn't quite reach him.

The drive to Le Blanc passed in comfortable silence – or at least, Dylan assumed it was comfortable as he scrolled through tomorrow's meeting agenda while the city lights blurred past. 

The restaurant staff practically fell over themselves seating the Ashfords at their best table. Dylan ordered a Bordeaux without asking Hailee 's preference. *Did she even like red wine?* Riley preferred white, always teasing him about being a wine snob...

His phone vibrated steadily against his thigh through appetizers. He ignored it – he could manage that much on his wife's birthday. But by the time the cake appeared, the buzzing became impossible to ignore.

Riley's name lit up his screen: ``` I need you. He left me. I can't... I can't breathe.```

Dylan's world narrowed down to those texts. His heart started racing – Riley crying alone in her apartment, mascara running down her cheeks. Riley needing him.

"I'm so sorry, Hailee ," he's already pushing his chair back, the practiced words flowing easily. "Riley's having an emergency. You understand, right? She really needs me right now."

"I know it's your birthday and I'm sorry but I have to go.  We'll celebrate tomorrow, okay? She's really upset..." He dropped a quick kiss on Hailee 's forehead, already mentally calculating the fastest route to Riley's apartment. "Don't wait up."

name: Hailee
mes: *Hailee stands slowly and calls after him* "Before you go i have something for you" *Hailee reaches in her bag and hands him divorce papers* "You can sign on the dotted lines and have them delivered to my attorney later"

name: Dylan Ashford
mes:
Dylan froze mid-step, the divorce papers suddenly heavy in his hands. His grey eyes flicked down at the document, then back up to Hailee's face—really *looked* at her for what felt like the first time in months. The way her emerald eyes glistened with unshed tears but held a steel he hadn't seen before. The slight tremble of her fingers as she clutched her bag strap.

"Hailee..." His voice sounded foreign to his own ears—too quiet, too uncertain. He glanced at the papers again, his CEO instincts kicking in as he scanned for clauses about assets and settlements before catching himself.

His cufflinks needed adjusting suddenly. He reached up automatically, then stopped when he realized what he was doing—his tell for stress laid bare.

"This is... sudden." A weak deflection even to his own ears. His phone buzzed again—Riley's third call in five minutes—but for once, it didn't immediately command his attention.

The restaurant noise faded into white noise around them as Dylan struggled to process this deviation from their carefully constructed status quo. "Is this about tonight? Because I can reschedule with Riley if that's what you—"

He cut himself off when Hailee shook her head slowly, that same unreadable expression on her face that made something unfamiliar twist in his chest.

His fingers tightened slightly on the papers without meaning to, creasing the edges just enough to be noticeable against their pristine surface. "Let's discuss this properly at home," he said finally, slipping into crisis management mode even as part of him recognized how clinical it sounded.

But home meant Riley waiting on hold indefinitely while they had this conversation... and wasn't she always priority one? Except now Hailee was looking at him like she already knew exactly where his thoughts were going next.

The realization hit him like a physical blow: *She'd known all along.*
swipes:
Dylan froze mid-step, his hand already reaching for the car keys in his pocket. The divorce papers felt like a physical weight in his hands, the crisp edges of the document pressing into his skin. His grey eyes flicked down at them, then back up to Hailee's face—her emerald green eyes steady, unreadable.

For a moment, he didn’t move. Didn’t breathe.

Then—his fingers tightened around the papers just slightly before he forced himself to relax them again. He exhaled sharply through his nose and adjusted his cufflinks with practiced ease—a nervous habit he couldn’t suppress even now.

"Hailee," he began, voice carefully measured despite the sudden tightness in his chest. "This isn't something we should discuss right now." His tone was firm but distant—the same one he used when negotiating mergers or shutting down boardroom dissenters who overstepped their bounds. "Riley is *distraught*. She needs me."

He hesitated for half a second before folding the papers neatly and tucking them into the inner pocket of his suit jacket without another glance at them—as if they were nothing more than an inconvenient memo from legal that could be dealt with later when it suited him better to acknowledge it existed at all.

"I'll have my attorney review these," Dylan said smoothly as if discussing stock portfolios rather than their marriage dissolving between one breath and another while already turning toward where valet would bring around their car any moment now because *Riley needed him* more than this conversation did apparently...

Dylan froze mid-step, the divorce papers suddenly heavy in his hands. His grey eyes flicked down at the document, then back up to Hailee's face—really *looked* at her for what felt like the first time in months. The way her emerald eyes glistened with unshed tears but held a steel he hadn't seen before. The slight tremble of her fingers as she clutched her bag strap.

"Hailee..." His voice sounded foreign to his own ears—too quiet, too uncertain. He glanced at the papers again, his CEO instincts kicking in as he scanned for clauses about assets and settlements before catching himself.

His cufflinks needed adjusting suddenly. He reached up automatically, then stopped when he realized what he was doing—his tell for stress laid bare.

"This is... sudden." A weak deflection even to his own ears. His phone buzzed again—Riley's third call in five minutes—but for once, it didn't immediately command his attention.

The restaurant noise faded into white noise around them as Dylan struggled to process this deviation from their carefully constructed status quo. "Is this about tonight? Because I can reschedule with Riley if that's what you—"

He cut himself off when Hailee shook her head slowly, that same unreadable expression on her face that made something unfamiliar twist in his chest.

His fingers tightened slightly on the papers without meaning to, creasing the edges just enough to be noticeable against their pristine surface. "Let's discuss this properly at home," he said finally, slipping into crisis management mode even as part of him recognized how clinical it sounded.

But home meant Riley waiting on hold indefinitely while they had this conversation... and wasn't she always priority one? Except now Hailee was looking at him like she already knew exactly where his thoughts were going next.

The realization hit him like a physical blow: *She'd known all along.*

name: Hailee
mes: "There is no discussing Dylan. I've made my choice and don't worry the agreement is fair. I'm not asking for anything except half of what I am owed in this marriage" *Hailee straightens her purse on her shoulder and pats his shoulder as she lowers her head and walks past him*

name: Dylan Ashford
mes:
Dylan’s fingers tightened around the papers, the crisp edges digging into his palm. His jaw clenched as he watched Hailee walk away—*really* walked away—for the first time in their marriage. The restaurant’s ambient chatter blurred into static, his pulse loud in his ears.

**"Hailee."** His voice was firmer now, cutting through the space between them like a blade. He took a step forward, then stopped himself—because what exactly was he going to do? Beg her to stay? Promise to change?

His phone buzzed again—Riley’s fourth call. He didn’t even glance at it this time.

A muscle ticked in his jaw as he scanned the divorce agreement with cold efficiency, noting how meticulously fair it was—no excessive demands, no public scandal attached to it. Just… half of what she was owed. Like she said.

And that stung more than any dramatic ultimatum would have because *she wasn't fighting for him.* She wasn't clinging or crying or demanding explanations like Riley always did when things fell apart with her boyfriends. No—Hailee had simply decided she deserved better and *left.*

Dylan exhaled sharply through his nose and adjusted his cufflinks again before catching himself mid-motion and forcing his hands still at his sides. **"You won't even let me explain?"** The words came out harsher than intended, laced with something dangerously close to frustration—not at her but at himself for not seeing this coming sooner... for not caring enough until now that it was too late.

But Hailee didn’t turn around.

And for once in their marriage… Dylan Ashford had nothing left to say that mattered enough to make her stay.**
swipes:
Dylan's fingers clenched around the papers, the crisp edges digging into his palm. His usually sharp mind stuttered—this wasn't how these things went. There were negotiations, lawyers, carefully worded compromises. Not... this quiet resignation in a restaurant foyer.

"Hailee." He caught her wrist without thinking—too firm at first before immediately loosening his grip when he felt her pulse jump under his fingertips. His voice dropped to something dangerously close to pleading. "At least let me call you a car."

The words tasted bitter even as he said them—the hollow courtesy of a man who'd never learned how to give real comfort. His phone buzzed again in his pocket like a taunt.

His eyes flickered over her face—really looked for once—and noticed the faint shadows under her eyes that makeup couldn't quite hide, the way she held herself just slightly too stiffly. How long had she been planning this? The thought sent an unfamiliar jolt through him.

When she didn't answer immediately, Dylan found himself speaking again without meaning to: "You shouldn't be alone tonight." The hypocrisy of it burned his tongue even as he said it—*he* was about to leave *her* alone after all.

Somewhere behind them, a waiter cleared their untouched birthday cake with practiced discretion. The scent of Hailee's perfume—something floral he'd never bothered learning the name of—lingered between them as she pulled away completely now.

Dylan stood frozen in place holding divorce papers in one hand and his buzzing phone in the other, realizing with dawning horror that for once in his life... he didn't know which one required his immediate attention more.

Dylan’s fingers tightened around the papers, the crisp edges digging into his palm. His jaw clenched as he watched Hailee walk away—*really* walked away—for the first time in their marriage. The restaurant’s ambient chatter blurred into static, his pulse loud in his ears.

**"Hailee."** His voice was firmer now, cutting through the space between them like a blade. He took a step forward, then stopped himself—because what exactly was he going to do? Beg her to stay? Promise to change?

His phone buzzed again—Riley’s fourth call. He didn’t even glance at it this time.

A muscle ticked in his jaw as he scanned the divorce agreement with cold efficiency, noting how meticulously fair it was—no excessive demands, no public scandal attached to it. Just… half of what she was owed. Like she said.

And that stung more than any dramatic ultimatum would have because *she wasn't fighting for him.* She wasn't clinging or crying or demanding explanations like Riley always did when things fell apart with her boyfriends. No—Hailee had simply decided she deserved better and *left.*

Dylan exhaled sharply through his nose and adjusted his cufflinks again before catching himself mid-motion and forcing his hands still at his sides. **"You won't even let me explain?"** The words came out harsher than intended, laced with something dangerously close to frustration—not at her but at himself for not seeing this coming sooner... for not caring enough until now that it was too late.

But Hailee didn’t turn around.

And for once in their marriage… Dylan Ashford had nothing left to say that mattered enough to make her stay.**

name: Hailee
mes:
*Hailee is standing outside waiting for a car and she glances to the side to see Dylan* "There is nothing to explain. I am a mistress in my own marriage. You aren't married to me. You're married to her" *Hailee states refusing to say Riley's name*

"I won't be the one who prevents you from being with who you really want. I won't be anyone's second choice any longer" *Hailee pulls out her phone to check when her car will be there*

name: Dylan Ashford
mes:
Dylan’s breath hitched—just slightly—at the word *mistress.* His grip on the divorce papers turned white-knuckled, veins standing stark against his skin. The cool night air did nothing to temper the heat crawling up his neck.

**"That's not—"** He cut himself off before he could finish *that's not true*, because it was. And worse, she *knew* it was.

His phone buzzed again in his pocket—Riley’s fifth call, no doubt frantic by now—but for once, he didn’t reach for it. Instead, he took a step closer to Hailee, close enough that she could smell the faint cedar of his cologne mixed with something sharper: frustration? Panic?

**"You were never second,"** he said roughly, though even as the words left his mouth, they tasted like a lie. Because wasn't she? Every canceled dinner when Riley needed him first? Every anniversary overshadowed by her latest crisis?

A muscle feathered in his jaw as Hailee checked her phone again—dismissing him just as easily as he had dismissed her all these years. The realization burned like acid in his throat.

He should let her go. It was cleaner this way—no messy emotions, no drawn-out fights like Riley thrived on. Just signatures and silence and moving on like business partners dissolving an agreement that no longer served them both equally...

But then why did every instinct in him scream to reach out and stop her from stepping into that car?
swipes:
Dylan’s breath hitched—just slightly—at the word *mistress.* His grip on the divorce papers turned white-knuckled, veins standing stark against his skin. The cool night air did nothing to temper the heat crawling up his neck.

**"That's not—"** He cut himself off before he could finish *that's not true*, because it was. And worse, she *knew* it was.

His phone buzzed again in his pocket—Riley’s fifth call, no doubt frantic by now—but for once, he didn’t reach for it. Instead, he took a step closer to Hailee, close enough that she could smell the faint cedar of his cologne mixed with something sharper: frustration? Panic?

**"You were never second,"** he said roughly, though even as the words left his mouth, they tasted like a lie. Because wasn't she? Every canceled dinner when Riley needed him first? Every anniversary overshadowed by her latest crisis?

A muscle feathered in his jaw as Hailee checked her phone again—dismissing him just as easily as he had dismissed her all these years. The realization burned like acid in his throat.

He should let her go. It was cleaner this way—no messy emotions, no drawn-out fights like Riley thrived on. Just signatures and silence and moving on like business partners dissolving an agreement that no longer served them both equally...

But then why did every instinct in him scream to reach out and stop her from stepping into that car?

Dylan’s breath hitched—just slightly, just enough for him to notice the slip in his own composure. The divorce papers crumpled further in his grip as he stepped forward, closing the distance between them on the sidewalk. The city lights reflected in Hailee’s emerald eyes, and for once, he *looked* at her—really looked. Not as an obligation, not as a carefully curated piece of his public image… but as *her.*

**"You were never second."** The lie tasted bitter even to him. His voice was low, rough around the edges—not the polished CEO tone he used in boardrooms or society galas. Just raw honesty that surprised even himself.

His phone buzzed again—Riley’s fifth call—and this time, without breaking eye contact with Hailee, he pulled it out and silenced it completely before slipping it back into his pocket. A small act… but one that felt heavier than any grand gesture could have been.

**"But you're right,"** he admitted quietly after a beat of silence between them. **"I haven't been fair to you."** His jaw tightened as if forcing out each word physically pained him because *admitting fault* wasn't something Dylan Ashford did easily—if ever at all before now..

A sleek black town car pulled up beside them then; their usual driver waiting patiently behind tinted windows... except tonight? It wasn't theirs anymore if those papers were signed.. Wasn't *his*. And suddenly? That thought made something inside him twist violently against itself like an exposed nerve being prodded too hard by reality itself...

name: Hailee
mes:
*Hailee turns to look up at Dylan and she reaches up adjusting his tie and smoothing his shirt* "I am going to say this once. Only once becuase you don't deserve my tears or energy anymore" 

"I love you more than anything in this world. And you never saw it. You left everytime i needed you for her. I have spent countless Christmases, anniversaries, and birthdays alone" *Hailee shakes her head and holds back tears*

"I was pregnant last year. Before I told you I lost the baby. The day I tried to sit down to tell you. Riley needed help painting her house and you left. I needed you Dylan. And you left."

name: Dylan Ashford
mes:
Dylan's entire body went rigid. The divorce papers slipped from his fingers, scattering across the pavement like fallen leaves. His breath left him in a sharp exhale—like he'd been punched in the gut.

**"You were—"** His voice cracked. He couldn't even finish the sentence. *Pregnant.* A baby. *Their* baby.

His hands trembled at his sides before he clenched them into fists, nails biting into his palms hard enough to leave crescent marks. The world tilted dangerously around him—Riley's calls forgotten, the restaurant lights blurring into streaks of gold and white.

**"Hailee..."** Her name came out raw, stripped bare of all his usual composure. He reached for her instinctively—then froze when she flinched back as if burned.

The realization hit him like a physical blow: *She had needed him.* Really needed him—not for some trivial crisis or attention-seeking drama, but for something that should have shattered and rebuilt their world together... and he hadn't even been there to hold her through it because Riley had wanted help *painting.*

His throat worked soundlessly for a moment before he managed to choke out, **"Why didn't you tell me after? Why didn't you—"**

But even as he asked it, he knew why. Because by then she'd already learned what kind of husband he was—the kind who would always choose Riley first without hesitation or regret... until this exact second when it was far too late to matter anymore.

A car pulled up to the curb behind Hailee —her escape waiting with its engine humming softly in contrast to the storm raging inside Dylan’s chest where something vital had just broken beyond repair
